page.title: 04CAERSALEM CHAPEL, SWANSEA
page.content: Caersalem Baptist Chapel, built in 1840, is of interest today because of its continued use of the Welsh language. Regular services held entirely in Welsh take place here. Welsh was the main spoken language of the area until the Second World War. Its decline can be attributed to the prewar arrival of immigrant workers needed to build the railway lines for the collieries and to the post-war construction of large housing estates, both private and Council. Caersalem is also of interest historically. The original chapel for the area was Mynyddbach Chapel (Nonconformist, built 1761). Contrasting views caused a split in this congregation and half set to work to build Caersalem, using local stone and the labour of 'strike-bound' miners.
